Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Regional Atmospheric Chemistry: State-of-the-art Measurement and Modeling in the Pacific Northwest
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program will educate early researchers in the exciting field of atmospheric chemistry, air quality and climate change. Students ranging from freshman to seniors will gain hands-on experience in research related to the field of atmospheric chemistry, and the program promotes the idea of interdisciplinary and collaborative research to encourage the participants to remain in a STEM discipline and pursue graduate school opportunities. The program will also broaden the diversity of participants to involve underrepresented students in engineering and science, including students from community colleges that do not have an opportunity to participate in research.

Understanding complex atmospheric chemical processes requires simultaneous measurements from numerous instruments, and sophisticated numerical models to bring the data together into a coherent scientific product. This makes atmospheric chemistry an ideal topic for introducing undergraduates to the scientific linkage between measurements and modeling and to the collaborative nature of environmental research. Goals for the program include developing technical expertise in science and engineering areas within the context of atmospheric chemistry, and engaging students in authentic research activities that lead to scientific publications and presentations; helping students understand the broad scope of atmospheric research so they understand how their research fits within the broader societal context of climate change; developing oral and written communication skills; providing opportunities for students to learn about career and graduate school options; recruiting a diverse set of student participants; and providing opportunities for participants to engage in productive and meaningful social interactions with faculty and graduate students so that participants will develop positive and productive beliefs about STEM fields and graduate school. Ten students will be recruited each summer, targeting underrepresented communities in the Pacific Northwest. Workshops during the 9.5-week program, will train students in atmospheric chemistry, measurement and modeling techniques, data interpretation, and scientific communication. In parallel with these workshops, students will be trained on the specific research tools required for their individual research projects with faculty and graduate student mentors. The students will form part of a larger community of scholars on campus and showcase their research during a final campus wide poster session.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Program trained 30 undergraduate students over three years at Washington State University (WSU). The Site, entitled: Regional Atmospheric Chemistry: State-of-the-art Measurement and Modeling in the Pacific Northwest, gave students hands-on experience conducting authentic research with a faculty mentor. Faculty and students were part of the Laboratory for Atmospheric Research (LAR), within the Civil and Environmental Engineering Dept. at WSU. During the 9 week summer experience, students participated in skill development workshops, professional development workshops, training in a specific research area, and presenting their research in the form of a poster symposium.

 

Intellectual merit: Participants that complete this REU experience report (>90%) that they have come to appreciate the science that goes into research, and they have gained confidence in running experiments and doing data analysis as a result of this program. Students were engaged in activities to help them understand the broad scope of atmospheric chemistry, air quality and climate change research. Students worked side by side with faculty, graduate students and other REU students within a community of scholars. At the end of the program, students participated in a poster presentation to share the results of their summer research. Over the course of the presentation they were rated on six categories that evaluate their intellectual merit: student position, novel contribution/innovative thinking, process/method, conclusion/outcome/creative product, presentation/display, and oral presentation. Scoring was done using a scale of 4 = Excellent, 3 = Good, 2 = Acceptable, 1 = Poor, and 0 =Absent. Overall, the REU students produced and presented good work throughout all three years of the program (see Figure 1). The overall combined average for the poster presentation scores was 3.21, indicating that the REU students produced good quality work.

 

Broader Impacts: Students ranging from freshman to seniors gain hands on experience in research related to atmospheric chemistry, air quality and climate change. The 30 REU participants were from various institutions, and were collectively 40% female, 57% male, 3% transgender, 30% underrepresented (African American, Hispanic or Multicultural), 7% non-traditional student, and 37% from high school, small universities or community colleges that do not have research opportunities. The program also actively recruits early career students and over three years 47% of the students trained were freshmen or sophomores. This program promotes the idea of interdisciplinary and collaborative research and encourages the participants to remain in a STEM discipline and pursue graduate school opportunities. Students were encouraged to present their research at a National conference such as the American Meteorological Society Annual Meeting or the American Geophysical Union Annual Meeting, and 16 (53%) of the students did this through funding from this grant, with several students presenting at multiple meetings. Students were also provided opportunities to learn about career and graduate school options, and in general exposed to positive and productive beliefs about Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields in hopes of developing our future STEM workforce.
